facts.text: Cordelia Montrose was the most celebrated bride-to-be in Long Beach society. Her wedding to Sebastian Crane was planned for late 1925.
Three people died in October 1925: Alice Whitmore, Sebastian Crane, and Cordelia Montrose. The deaths were shrouded in secrecy and quickly covered up.
The Montrose family changed their public narrative after 1925. Several family members moved away. There was a deliberate effort to distance the family from what happened.
The mansion on Kennebec Avenue has been in the Montrose family for generations. It contains original furniture and belongings from the 1920s era.
Dr. Thaddeus Crane was the town physician in Long Beach in 1925. He was respected and trusted by the community.
The Crane family changed their surname from Crane to Sinclair in the 1960s. The official reason given was for business and privacy purposes.
Three deaths in October 1925 were officially attributed to accident, homicide, and natural causes. All three were pronounced by the same physician.
The Crane family has a dark history. Something significant happened to the family around 1925 that they have kept secret for nearly 100 years.
Silas Blackwell was the mortician in 1925. The autopsy records are still at the mortuary.
The Montrose family fortune is substantial and has been managed through trusts dating back to the 19th century.
Sebastian Crane and Cordelia Montrose signed a pre-nuptial agreement on August 15, 1925. They were engaged.
Large payments were made from the Montrose estate in October 1925 to cover 'discretionary expenses' and 'legal matters.'
Professor Hartley was a celebrated predecessor who was an accomplished botanist and naturalist. He was highly respected in academic circles in 1920s.
The previous Professor Hartley was known for his willingness to consult on botanical matters for various businesses and entrepreneurs during the Prohibition era.

The predecessor Professor Hartley was a charming, ambitious man who believed in practical applications of botanical knowledge and didn't concern himself too much with the ethics of his clients' intentions.
Elias Monroe was a talented dressmaker who created wedding gowns for prominent Long Beach families.
Cordelia Montrose's wedding dress was created with meticulous care but remained unworn. She never became a bride.
The wedding dress contains a lock of Cordelia's hair—likely from her final dress fitting before she died.
Cordelia Montrose disappeared for months in early 1925, then returned changed and withdrawn. Even her best friend Alice hadn't seen her.
Elias Monroe kept notes on a rose bread recipe that Cordelia gave him—she wanted the recipe passed to Eleanor Sullivan. This suggests a deep family connection between Cordelia and Eleanor.
Cordelia's personal diary is in the possession of the Heiress. The Dressmaker knows this and believes the diary is essential to understanding what truly happened to Cordelia.
The mansion on Kennebec Avenue contains many rooms that have been sealed or unused for decades.
There is an abandoned garage on the Montrose property that appears to have been deliberately sealed in 1925.
There was a celebrated psychic medium in the 1920s who was known throughout Long Beach society for genuine abilities and accurate readings.
Alice Whitmore was trained by and worked closely with that predecessor psychic medium. Alice was considered one of the most gifted students.
The predecessor medium's journals and notes are kept in the family archives. They contain records of readings and spiritual consultations from the 1920s.
The Romano family controlled significant business operations in Long Beach, particularly at the harbor.
Frankie Romano was known as a shrewd businessman with connections to illegal smuggling operations during Prohibition.
Several valuable artifacts in the mansion are actually Romano family imports—pieces smuggled through their operation.
The Sullivan family bakery was destroyed in a fire in the 1980s-1990s. The fire was never properly investigated.
Eleanor Sullivan is part of the Sullivan family but there are hints that she may have a connection to the Montrose family.

Cordelia Montrose disappeared from Long Beach for three months in early 1925 (May-August). Family records show she was sent on an 'extended European tour,' but no passenger records exist for this journey.
After her mysterious disappearance, Cordelia returned visibly changed—thinner, sadder, with a haunted expression. She was distant and reclusive for weeks, avoiding her usual social circles.
facts.source: Personal observation / Elias Monroe's journal notes

facts.text: From Dr. Thaddeus's medical notes: 'October 10, 1925 - I have made a terrible mistake. I cannot undo what has been done. Sebastian is dying and it is my fault.'
facts.source: Dr. Thaddeus Crane's Private Notes (found by Doctor)
